# useStorage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#usestorage)

Category

[State](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=State)

Export Size

2 kB

Last Changed

last month

Related

[`useColorMode`](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/) [`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) [`useLocalStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useLocalStorage/) [`useSessionStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useSessionStorage/) [`useStorageAsync`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorageAsync/)

Create a reactive ref that can be used to access & modify [LocalStorage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/localStorage) or [SessionStorage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/sessionStorage).

Uses localStorage by default, other storage sources be specified via third argument.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useStorage/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

```
name: Banana
color: Yellow
size: Medium
count: 0

```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#usage)

TIP

When using with Nuxt 3, this function will **NOT** be auto imported in favor of Nitro's built-in [`useStorage()`](https://nitro.unjs.io/guide/storage). Use explicit import if you want to use the function from VueUse.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

// bind object
const
 =
('my-store', {
: 'hi',
: 'Hello' })

// bind boolean
const
 =
('my-flag', true) // returns Ref<boolean>

// bind number
const
 =
('my-count', 0) // returns Ref<number>

// bind string with SessionStorage
const
 =
('my-id', 'some-string-id',
) // returns Ref<string>

// delete data from storage

.
 = null
```

## Merge Defaults [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#merge-defaults)

By default, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) will use the value from storage if it is present and ignores the default value. Be aware that when you are adding more properties to the default value, the key might be `undefined` if client's storage does not have that key.

ts

```

.
('my-store', '{"hello": "hello"}')

const
 =
('my-store', {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },
)

.
(
.
.
) // undefined, since the value is not presented in storage
```

To solve that, you can enable `mergeDefaults` option.

TypeScript

ts

```

.
('my-store', '{"hello": "nihao"}')

const
 =
(
  'my-store',
  {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },

,
  {
: true } // <--
)

.
(
.
.
) // 'nihao', from storage

.
(
.
.
) // 'hello', from merged default value
```

js

```
localStorage.setItem('my-store', '{"hello": "nihao"}')
const state = useStorage(
  'my-store',
  { hello: 'hi', greeting: 'hello' },
  localStorage,
  { mergeDefaults: true },
)
console.log(state.value.hello) // 'nihao', from storage
console.log(state.value.greeting) // 'hello', from merged default value
```

When setting it to true, it will perform a **shallow merge** for objects. You can pass a function to perform custom merge (e.g. deep merge), for example:

TypeScript

ts

```
const
 =
(
  'my-store',
  {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },

,
  {
: (
,
) => deepMerge(
,
) } // <--
)
```

js

```
const state = useStorage(
  'my-store',
  { hello: 'hi', greeting: 'hello' },
  localStorage,
  {
    mergeDefaults: (storageValue, defaults) =>
      deepMerge(defaults, storageValue),
  },
)
```

## Custom Serialization [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#custom-serialization)

By default, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) will smartly use the corresponding serializer based on the data type of provided default value. For example, `JSON.stringify` / `JSON.parse` will be used for objects, `Number.toString` / `parseFloat` for numbers, etc.

You can also provide your own serialization function to [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/):

TypeScript

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
  'key',
  {},

,
  {


: {


: (
: any) =>
 ?
.
(
) : null,


: (
: any) =>
.
(
),
    },
  },
)
```

js

```
import { useStorage } from '@vueuse/core'
useStorage('key', {}, undefined, {
  serializer: {
    read: (v) => (v ? JSON.parse(v) : null),
    write: (v) => JSON.stringify(v),
  },
})
```

Please note when you provide `null` as the default value, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) can't assume the data type from it. In this case, you can provide a custom serializer or reuse the built-in ones explicitly.

ts

```
import {
,
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('key', null,
, {
:
.
 })

.
 = {
: 'bar' }
```

# useClipboard [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboard/\#useclipboard)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

1.44 kB

Last Changed

2 months ago

Related

[`useClipboardItems`](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboardItems/)

Reactive [Clipboard API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API). Provides the ability to respond to clipboard commands (cut, copy, and paste) as well as to asynchronously read from and write to the system clipboard. Access to the contents of the clipboard is gated behind the [Permissions API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Permissions_API). Without user permission, reading or altering the clipboard contents is not permitted.

[Learn how to reactively save text to the clipboard with this FREE video lesson from Vue School!](https://vueschool.io/lessons/reactive-browser-wrappers-in-vueuse-useclipboard?friend=vueuse)

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboard/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useClipboard/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Clipboard Permission: read **prompt** \| write **granted**

Current copied: `none`

Copy

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboard/\#usage)

vue

import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =

">

(
)">
      <!-- by default, `copied` will be reset in 1.5s -->

 v-if="!
">Copy</
>
      <
 v-else>Copied!</
>
    </
>
    <
>Current copied: <
>{{
 || 'none' }}</
></
>
  </
>
  <
 v-else>
    Your browser does not support Clipboard API
  </
>
</template>
```

Set `legacy: true` to keep the ability to copy if [Clipboard API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API) is not available. It will handle copy with [execCommand](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/execCommand) as fallback.

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboard/\#component-usage)

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useStorage/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

```
name: Banana
color: Yellow
size: Medium
count: 0

```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#usage)

TIP

When using with Nuxt 3, this function will **NOT** be auto imported in favor of Nitro's built-in [`useStorage()`](https://nitro.unjs.io/guide/storage). Use explicit import if you want to use the function from VueUse.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

// bind object
const
 =
('my-store', {
: 'hi',
: 'Hello' })

// bind boolean
const
 =
('my-flag', true) // returns Ref<boolean>

// bind number
const
 =
('my-count', 0) // returns Ref<number>

// bind string with SessionStorage
const
 =
('my-id', 'some-string-id',
) // returns Ref<string>

// delete data from storage

.
 = null
```

## Merge Defaults [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#merge-defaults)

By default, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) will use the value from storage if it is present and ignores the default value. Be aware that when you are adding more properties to the default value, the key might be `undefined` if client's storage does not have that key.

ts

```

.
('my-store', '{"hello": "hello"}')

const
 =
('my-store', {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },
)

.
(
.
.
) // undefined, since the value is not presented in storage
```

To solve that, you can enable `mergeDefaults` option.

TypeScript

ts

```

.
('my-store', '{"hello": "nihao"}')

const
 =
(
  'my-store',
  {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },

,
  {
: true } // <--
)

.
(
.
.
) // 'nihao', from storage

.
(
.
.
) // 'hello', from merged default value
```

js

```
localStorage.setItem('my-store', '{"hello": "nihao"}')
const state = useStorage(
  'my-store',
  { hello: 'hi', greeting: 'hello' },
  localStorage,
  { mergeDefaults: true },
)
console.log(state.value.hello) // 'nihao', from storage
console.log(state.value.greeting) // 'hello', from merged default value
```

When setting it to true, it will perform a **shallow merge** for objects. You can pass a function to perform custom merge (e.g. deep merge), for example:

TypeScript

ts

```
const
 =
(
  'my-store',
  {
: 'hi',
: 'hello' },

,
  {
: (
,
) => deepMerge(
,
) } // <--
)
```

js

```
const state = useStorage(
  'my-store',
  { hello: 'hi', greeting: 'hello' },
  localStorage,
  {
    mergeDefaults: (storageValue, defaults) =>
      deepMerge(defaults, storageValue),
  },
)
```

## Custom Serialization [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/\#custom-serialization)

By default, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) will smartly use the corresponding serializer based on the data type of provided default value. For example, `JSON.stringify` / `JSON.parse` will be used for objects, `Number.toString` / `parseFloat` for numbers, etc.

You can also provide your own serialization function to [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/):

TypeScript

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
  'key',
  {},

,
  {


: {


: (
: any) =>
 ?
.
(
) : null,


: (
: any) =>
.
(
),
    },
  },
)
```

js

```
import { useStorage } from '@vueuse/core'
useStorage('key', {}, undefined, {
  serializer: {
    read: (v) => (v ? JSON.parse(v) : null),
    write: (v) => JSON.stringify(v),
  },
})
```

Please note when you provide `null` as the default value, [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/) can't assume the data type from it. In this case, you can provide a custom serializer or reuse the built-in ones explicitly.

ts

```
import {
,
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('key', null,
, {
:
.
 })

.
 = {
: 'bar' }
```

# useClipboard [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboard/\#useclipboard)

Export Size

1.44 kB

2 months ago

Related

[`useClipboardItems`](https://vueuse.org/core/useClipboardItems/)

Reactive [Clipboard API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API). Provides the ability to respond to clipboard commands (cut, copy, and paste) as well as to asynchronously read from and write to the system clipboard. Access to the contents of the clipboard is gated behind the [Permissions API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Permissions_API). Without user permission, reading or altering the clipboard contents is not permitted.

[Learn how to reactively save text to the clipboard with this FREE video lesson from Vue School!](https://vueschool.io/lessons/reactive-browser-wrappers-in-vueuse-useclipboard?friend=vueuse)

Current copied: `none`

Set `legacy: true` to keep the ability to copy if [Clipboard API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API) is not available. It will handle copy with [execCommand](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/execCommand) as fallback.

Reactive dark mode with auto data persistence.

[Learn useDark with this FREE video lesson from Vue School!](https://vueschool.io/lessons/theming-with-vueuse-usedark-and-usecolormode?friend=vueuse)

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useDark/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Light

## Basic Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#basic-usage)

ts

```
import {
,
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
()
const
 =
(
)
```

## Behavior [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#behavior)

[`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) combines with [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) and [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/). On start up, it reads the value from localStorage/sessionStorage (the key is configurable) to see if there is a user configured color scheme, if not, it will use users' system preferences. When you change the `isDark` ref, it will update the corresponding element's attribute and then store the preference to storage (default key: `vueuse-color-scheme`) for persistence.

> Please note [`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) only handles the DOM attribute changes for you to apply proper selector in your CSS. It does NOT handle the actual style, theme or CSS for you.

## Configuration [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#configuration)

By default, it uses [Tailwind CSS favored dark mode](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode#toggling-dark-mode-manually), which enables dark mode when class `dark` is applied to the `html` tag, for example:

html

```
<!--light-->
<html>
  ...
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html class="dark">
  ...
</html>
```

Still, you can also customize it to make it work with most CSS frameworks.

For example:

ts

```
const
 =
({

: 'body',

: 'color-scheme',

: 'dark',

: 'light',
})
```

will work like

html

```
<!--light-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="light">
    ...
  </body>
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="dark">
    ...
  </body>
</html>
```

If the configuration above still does not fit your needs, you can use the `onChanged` option to take full control over how you handle updates.

ts

```
const
 =
({

(
) {
    // update the dom, call the API or something
  },
})
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#component-usage)

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

,
 }">

 @
="
()">
      Is Dark: {{
 }}
    </

  </UseDark>
</template>
```

# useDark [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#usedark)

Related

Reactive dark mode with auto data persistence.

[Learn useDark with this FREE video lesson from Vue School!](https://vueschool.io/lessons/theming-with-vueuse-usedark-and-usecolormode?friend=vueuse)

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useDark/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Light

## Basic Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#basic-usage)

ts

```
import {
,
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
()
const
 =
(
)
```

## Behavior [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#behavior)

[`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) combines with [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) and [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/). On start up, it reads the value from localStorage/sessionStorage (the key is configurable) to see if there is a user configured color scheme, if not, it will use users' system preferences. When you change the `isDark` ref, it will update the corresponding element's attribute and then store the preference to storage (default key: `vueuse-color-scheme`) for persistence.

> Please note [`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) only handles the DOM attribute changes for you to apply proper selector in your CSS. It does NOT handle the actual style, theme or CSS for you.

## Configuration [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#configuration)

By default, it uses [Tailwind CSS favored dark mode](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode#toggling-dark-mode-manually), which enables dark mode when class `dark` is applied to the `html` tag, for example:

html

```
<!--light-->
<html>
  ...
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html class="dark">
  ...
</html>
```

Still, you can also customize it to make it work with most CSS frameworks.

For example:

ts

```
const
 =
({

: 'body',

: 'color-scheme',

: 'dark',

: 'light',
})
```

will work like

html

```
<!--light-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="light">
    ...
  </body>
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="dark">
    ...
  </body>
</html>
```

If the configuration above still does not fit your needs, you can use the `onChanged` option to take full control over how you handle updates.

ts

```
const
 =
({

(
) {
    // update the dom, call the API or something
  },
})
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/\#component-usage)

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

vue

```
<template>
  <UseDark v-slot="{
,
 }">
    <
 @
="
()">
      Is Dark: {{
 }}
    </
>
  </UseDark>
</template>
```

  "markdown": "[Skip to content](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/#VPContent)

On this page

# useColorMode [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#usecolormode)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

3.14 kB

Last Changed

3 months ago

Related

[`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/)

Reactive color mode (dark / light / customs) with auto data persistence.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useColorMode/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

autoâ† Click to change the color mode

## Basic Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#basic-usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
() // Ref<'dark' | 'light'>
```

By default, it will match with users' browser preference using [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) (a.k.a `auto` mode). When reading the ref, it will by default return the current color mode ( `dark`, `light` or your custom modes). The `auto` mode can be included in the returned modes by enabling the `emitAuto` option. When writing to the ref, it will trigger DOM updates and persist the color mode to local storage (or your custom storage). You can pass `auto` to set back to auto mode.

ts

```

.
 // 'dark' | 'light'

.
 = 'dark' // change to dark mode and persist

.
 = 'auto' // change to auto mode
```

## Config [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#config)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
({

: 'theme',

: {
    // custom colors

: 'dim',

: 'cafe',
  },
}) // Ref<'dark' | 'light' | 'dim' | 'cafe'>
```

## Advanced Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#advanced-usage)

You can also explicit access to the system preference and storaged user override mode.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const {
,
 } =
()

.
 // 'dark' | 'light'

.
 // 'dark' | 'light' | 'auto'

const
 =
(() =>
.
 === 'auto' ?
.
 :
.
)
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#component-usage)

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

vue

```
<template>
  <UseColorMode v-slot="
">
    <
 @
="
.mode =
.mode === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark'">
      Mode {{
.mode }}
    </
>
  </UseColorMode>
</template>
```

## Type Declarations [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#type-declarations)

Show Type Declarations

# useColorMode [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#usecolormode)

Category

3.14 kB

Last Changed

3 months ago

Related

[`useDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/useDark/) [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) [`useStorage`](https://vueuse.org/core/useStorage/)

Reactive color mode (dark / light / customs) with auto data persistence.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useColorMode/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

autoâ† Click to change the color mode

## Basic Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#basic-usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
() // Ref<'dark' | 'light'>
```

By default, it will match with users' browser preference using [`usePreferredDark`](https://vueuse.org/core/usePreferredDark/) (a.k.a `auto` mode). When reading the ref, it will by default return the current color mode ( `dark`, `light` or your custom modes). The `auto` mode can be included in the returned modes by enabling the `emitAuto` option. When writing to the ref, it will trigger DOM updates and persist the color mode to local storage (or your custom storage). You can pass `auto` to set back to auto mode.

ts

```

.
 // 'dark' | 'light'

.
 = 'dark' // change to dark mode and persist

.
 = 'auto' // change to auto mode
```

## Config [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#config)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
({

: 'theme',

: {
    // custom colors

: 'dim',

: 'cafe',
  },
}) // Ref<'dark' | 'light' | 'dim' | 'cafe'>
```

## Advanced Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#advanced-usage)

You can also explicit access to the system preference and storaged user override mode.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const {
,
 } =
()

.
 // 'dark' | 'light'

.
 // 'dark' | 'light' | 'auto'

const
 =
(() =>
.
 === 'auto' ?
.
 :
.
)
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useColorMode/\#component-usage)

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

vue

```
<template>
  <UseColorMode v-slot="
">
    <
 @
="
.mode =
.mode === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark'">
      Mode {{
.mode }}
    </
>
  </UseColorMode>
</template>
```

Tracks the visibility of an element within the viewport.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useElementVisibility/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useElementVisibility/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Info on the right bottom corner

Target Element (scroll down)

Element inside the viewport

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useElementVisibility/\#usage)

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {

import {

const
 =
<HTMLDivElement>('target')
const
 =
(
)
</script>

="
">
    <
>Hello world</
>
  </

</template>
```

### rootMargin [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useElementVisibility/\#rootmargin)

If you wish to trigger your callback sooner before the element is fully visible, you can use the `rootMargin` option (See [MDN IntersectionObserver/rootMargin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/rootMargin)).

ts

```
const
 =
(target, {

: '0px 0px 100px 0px',
})
```

### threshold [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useElementVisibility/\#threshold)

If you want to control the percentage of the visibility required to update the value, you can use the `threshold` option (See [MDN IntersectionObserver/threshold](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/IntersectionObserver#threshold)).

ts

```
const
 = useElementVisibility(target, {

: 1.0, // 100% visible
})
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useElementVisibility/\#component-usage)

 }">

ty="

="
">

ty="

">

>

```

# useDark

Category: [Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size: 3.24 kB

Reactive dark mode with auto data persistence.

[Learn useDark with this FREE video lesson from Vue School!](https://vueschool.io/lessons/theming-with-vueuse-usedark-and-usecolormode?friend=vueuse)

## Basic Usage

```ts
import { useDark, useToggle } from '@vueuse/core'

const isDark = useDark()
const toggleDark = useToggle(isDark)
```

## Behavior

`useDark` combines with `usePreferredDark` and `useStorage`. On start up, it reads the value from localStorage/sessionStorage (the key is configurable) to see if there is a user configured color scheme, if not, it will use users' system preferences. When you change the `isDark` ref, it will update the corresponding element's attribute and then store the preference to storage (default key: `vueuse-color-scheme`) for persistence.

> Please note `useDark` only handles the DOM attribute changes for you to apply proper selector in your CSS. It does NOT handle the actual style, theme or CSS for you.

## Configuration

By default, it uses [Tailwind CSS favored dark mode](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode#toggling-dark-mode-manually), which enables dark mode when class `dark` is applied to the `html` tag, for example:

```html
<!--light-->
<html>
  ...
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html class="dark">
  ...
</html>
```

Still, you can also customize it to make it work with most CSS frameworks.

For example:

```ts
const isDark = useDark({
  selector: 'body',
  attribute: 'color-scheme',
  valueDark: 'dark',
  valueLight: 'light',
})
```

will work like

```html
<!--light-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="light">
    ...
  </body>
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="dark">
    ...
  </body>
</html>
```

If the configuration above still does not fit your needs, you can use the `onChanged` option to take full control over how you handle updates.

```ts
const isDark = useDark({
  onChanged(dark) {
    // update the dom, call the API or something
  },
})
```

## Component Usage

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

```vue
<template>
  <UseDark v-slot="{ isDark, toggleDark }">
    <button @click="toggleDark()">
      Is Dark: {{ isDark }}
    </button>
  </UseDark>
</template>
```

[Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useDark/index.ts)

# useColorMode

Category: [Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size: 3.14 kB

Reactive color mode (dark / light / customs) with auto data persistence.

## Basic Usage

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const mode = useColorMode() // Ref<'dark' | 'light'>
```

By default, it will match with users' browser preference using `usePreferredDark` (a.k.a `auto` mode). When reading the ref, it will by default return the current color mode ( `dark`, `light` or your custom modes). The `auto` mode can be included in the returned modes by enabling the `emitAuto` option. When writing to the ref, it will trigger DOM updates and persist the color mode to local storage (or your custom storage). You can pass `auto` to set back to auto mode.

```ts
mode.value // 'dark' | 'light'

mode.value = 'dark' // change to dark mode and persist

mode.value = 'auto' // change to auto mode
```

## Config

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const mode = useColorMode({
  attribute: 'theme',
  modes: {
    // custom colors
    dim: 'dim',
    cafe: 'cafe',
  },
}) // Ref<'dark' | 'light' | 'dim' | 'cafe'>
```

## Advanced Usage

You can also explicit access to the system preference and storaged user override mode.

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const { store, system } = useColorMode()

system.value // 'dark' | 'light'

store.value // 'dark' | 'light' | 'auto'

const preferredMode = computed(() =>
  store.value === 'auto' ? system.value : store.value
)
```

## Component Usage

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

```vue
<template>
  <UseColorMode v-slot="{ mode }">
    <button @click="mode.mode = mode.mode === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark'">
      Mode {{ mode.mode }}
    </button>
  </UseColorMode>
</template>
```

[Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useColorMode/index.ts)

```

Still, you can also customize it to make it work with most CSS frameworks.

For example:

```ts
const isDark = useDark({
  selector: 'body',
  attribute: 'color-scheme',
  valueDark: 'dark',
  valueLight: 'light',
})
```

will work like

```html
<!--light-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="light">
    ...
  </body>
</html>

<!--dark-->
<html>
  <body color-scheme="dark">
    ...
  </body>
</html>
```

If the configuration above still does not fit your needs, you can use the `onChanged` option to take full control over how you handle updates.

```ts
const isDark = useDark({
  onChanged(dark) {
    // update the dom, call the API or something
  },
})
```

## Component Usage

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

```vue
<template>
  <UseDark v-slot="{ isDark, toggleDark }">
    <button @click="toggleDark()">
      Is Dark: {{ isDark }}
    </button>
  </UseDark>
</template>
```

[Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useDark/index.ts)

# useColorMode

Category: [Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size: 3.14 kB

Reactive color mode (dark / light / customs) with auto data persistence.

## Basic Usage

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const mode = useColorMode() // Ref<'dark' | 'light'>
```

By default, it will match with users' browser preference using `usePreferredDark` (a.k.a `auto` mode). When reading the ref, it will by default return the current color mode ( `dark`, `light` or your custom modes). The `auto` mode can be included in the returned modes by enabling the `emitAuto` option. When writing to the ref, it will trigger DOM updates and persist the color mode to local storage (or your custom storage). You can pass `auto` to set back to auto mode.

```ts
mode.value // 'dark' | 'light'

mode.value = 'dark' // change to dark mode and persist

mode.value = 'auto' // change to auto mode
```

## Config

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const mode = useColorMode({
  attribute: 'theme',
  modes: {
    // custom colors
    dim: 'dim',
    cafe: 'cafe',
  },
}) // Ref<'dark' | 'light' | 'dim' | 'cafe'>
```

## Advanced Usage

You can also explicit access to the system preference and storaged user override mode.

```ts
import { useColorMode } from '@vueuse/core'

const { store, system } = useColorMode()

system.value // 'dark' | 'light'

store.value // 'dark' | 'light' | 'auto'

const preferredMode = computed(() =>
  store.value === 'auto' ? system.value : store.value
)
```

## Component Usage

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

```vue
<template>
  <UseColorMode v-slot="{ mode }">
    <button @click="mode.mode = mode.mode === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark'">
      Mode {{ mode.mode }}
    </button>
  </UseColorMode>
</template>
```

[Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useColorMode/index.ts)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

TypeScript

```
import {

import {

const

<HTMLElement>('el')
const {

(
, {
: 'smooth' })

// Or as a `ref`:
const

(false)
const

(() =>
.

const {
,

(
, {
 })
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

TypeScript

ts

```
import {

import {
,
,
,

const
 =
<HTMLElement>('el')
const
 =
(false)

const {
 } =
(
)

// In a watcher

(
, () => {

()
})

// Or inside any function
function
() {
  // ...some logic

(() => {

()
  })
}
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

On this page

# useEventListener [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#useeventlistener)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

588 B

Last Changed

2 months ago

Use EventListener with ease. Register using [addEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener) on mounted, and [removeEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/removeEventListener) automatically on unmounted.

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
, 'visibilitychange', (
) => {

.
(
)
})
```

You can also pass a ref as the event target, [`useEventListener`](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/) will unregister the previous event and register the new one when you change the target.

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
('element')

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})
</script>

<template>
  <
 v-if="cond"
="
">
    Div1
  </
>
  <
 v-else
="
">
    Div2
  </
>
</template>
```

You can also call the returned to unregister the listener.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})

() // This will unregister the listener.
```

Note if your components also run in SSR (Server Side Rendering), you might get errors (like `document is not defined`) because DOM APIs like `document` and `window` are not available in Node.js. To avoid that you can put the logic inside `onMounted` hook.

ts

```
// onMounted will only be called in the client side
// so it guarantees the DOM APIs are available.

(() => {

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
  })
})
```

# useEventListener [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#useeventlistener)

Category

Export Size

588 B

Last Changed

2 months ago

Use EventListener with ease. Register using [addEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener) on mounted, and [removeEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/removeEventListener) automatically on unmounted.

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
, 'visibilitychange', (
) => {

.
(
)
})
```

You can also pass a ref as the event target, [`useEventListener`](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/) will unregister the previous event and register the new one when you change the target.

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
('element')

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})
</script>

<template>
  <
 v-if="cond"
="
">
    Div1
  </
>
  <
 v-else
="
">
    Div2
  </
>
</template>
```

You can also call the returned to unregister the listener.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})

() // This will unregister the listener.
```

Note if your components also run in SSR (Server Side Rendering), you might get errors (like `document is not defined`) because DOM APIs like `document` and `window` are not available in Node.js. To avoid that you can put the logic inside `onMounted` hook.

ts

```
// onMounted will only be called in the client side
// so it guarantees the DOM APIs are available.

(() => {

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
  })
})
```

  "markdown": "[Skip to content](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/#VPContent)

On this page

# useMediaQuery [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#usemediaquery)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

1.17 kB

Last Changed

7 months ago

Reactive [Media Query](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Media_Queries/Testing_media_queries). Once you've created a MediaQueryList object, you can check the result of the query or receive notifications when the result changes.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useMediaQuery/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

```
isLargeScreen: true
prefersDark: false

```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)')
const
 =
('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)')
```

#### Server Side Rendering and Nuxt [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#server-side-rendering-and-nuxt)

If you are using [`useMediaQuery`](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/) with SSR enabled, then you need to specify which screen size you would like to render on the server and before hydration to avoid an hydration mismatch

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)', {

: 768 // Will enable SSR mode and render like if the screen was 768px wide
})

.
(
.
) // always false because ssrWidth of 768px is smaller than 1024px

(() => {

.
(
.
) // false if screen is smaller than 1024px, true if larger than 1024px
})
```

Alternatively you can set this up globally for your app using [`provideSSRWidth`](https://vueuse.org/core/useSSRWidth/)

## Type Declarations [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#type-declarations)

ts

```
/**
 * Reactive Media Query.
 *
 * @see https://vueuse.org/useMediaQuery
 * @param query
 * @param options
 */
export declare function
(

:
<string>,

?:
 & {

?: number
  },
):
<boolean>
```

import {

#### Server Side Rendering and Nuxt [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#server-side-rendering-and-nuxt)

If you are using [`useMediaQuery`](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/) with SSR enabled, then you need to specify which screen size you would like to render on the server and before hydration to avoid an hydration mismatch

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)', {

: 768 // Will enable SSR mode and render like if the screen was 768px wide
})

.

.
) // always false because ssrWidth of 768px is smaller than 1024px

(() => {

.
(
.
) // false if screen is smaller than 1024px, true if larger than 1024px
})
```

Alternatively you can set this up globally for your app using [`provideSSRWidth`](https://vueuse.org/core/useSSRWidth/)

[ResizeObserver MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ResizeObserver) ## Usage ```vue ``` ## Component Usage > This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. ```vue ``` ## Directive Usage > This function also provides a directive version via the `@vueuse/components` package. ```vue ``` [Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useElementSize/index.ts)

# useElementVisibility Category: [Elements](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Elements) Export Size: 793 B Tracks the visibility of an element within the viewport. ## Usage ```vue ``` ### rootMargin If you wish to trigger your callback sooner before the element is fully visible, you can use the `rootMargin` option (See [MDN IntersectionObserver/rootMargin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/rootMargin)). ```ts const targetIsVisible = useElementVisibility(target, { rootMargin: '0px 0px 100px 0px', }) ``` ### threshold If you want to control the percentage of the visibility required to update the value, you can use the `threshold` option (See [MDN IntersectionObserver/threshold](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/IntersectionObserver#threshold)). ```ts const targetIsVisible = useElementVisibility(target, { threshold: 1.0, // 100% visible }) ``` ## Component Usage ```vue ``` [Source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useElementVisibility/index.ts)

input.content:
# VueUse Functions Index

This document lists all the VueUse composables that have been scraped and saved to this directory.

## State Management

- **useStorage** - Reactive LocalStorage/SessionStorage with auto persistence
- **useLocalStorage** - Reactive LocalStorage wrapper
- **useSessionStorage** - Reactive SessionStorage wrapper

## Browser

- **useDark** - Reactive dark mode with auto data persistence
- **useColorMode** - Reactive color mode (dark/light/custom) with auto data persistence
- **useClipboard** - Reactive Clipboard API for copy/paste operations
- **useEventListener** - Easy addEventListener on mounted, auto removeEventListener on unmounted
- **useMediaQuery** - Reactive Media Query for responsive design

## Network

- **useFetch** - Reactive Fetch API with abort, intercept, and auto-refetch capabilities

## Elements

- **useElementSize** - Reactive size of an HTML element using ResizeObserver
- **useElementVisibility** - Tracks visibility of an element within the viewport
- **useResizeObserver** - Reports changes to dimensions of an Element's content or border-box
- **useIntersectionObserver** - Detects target element's visibility using IntersectionObserver

## Sensors

- **useMouse** - Reactive mouse position with support for touch events
- **useScroll** - Reactive scroll position and state with arrival detection

## Usage Notes

### Nuxt 3 Compatibility

Some composables like `useFetch` and `useStorage` are NOT auto-imported in Nuxt 3 to avoid conflicts with Nuxt's built-in composables. Use explicit imports:

```ts
import { useFetch, useStorage } from '@vueuse/core'
```

### Component Versions

Many functions provide renderless component versions via `@vueuse/components`:

```vue
<template>
  <UseMouse v-slot="{ x, y }">
    x: {{ x }}
    y: {{ y }}
  </UseMouse>
</template>
```

### Directive Versions

Some functions also provide directive versions:

```vue
<script setup>
import { vElementSize } from '@vueuse/components'

function onResize({ width, height }) {
  console.log(width, height)
}
</script>

<template>
  <div v-element-size="onResize" />
</template>
```

## Documentation Source

All documentation was scraped from [https://vueuse.org](https://vueuse.org) on October 1, 2025.

## File Organization

Each composable has its own markdown file named after the function (e.g., `useMouse.md`, `useStorage.md`). These files contain:

- Function overview and description
- Basic usage examples
- Configuration options
- Component and directive usage (when available)
- Type declarations
- Links to source code

## Additional Resources

- [VueUse Official Documentation](https://vueuse.org)
- [VueUse GitHub Repository](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse)
- [Vue School Video Lessons](https://vueschool.io/lessons?friend=vueuse)

### Directive Versions

Some functions also provide directive versions:

```vue
<script setup>
import { vElementSize } from '@vueuse/components'

function onResize({ width, height }) {
  console.log(width, height)
}
</script>

<template>
  <div v-element-size="onResize" />
</template>
```

## Documentation Source

All documentation was scraped from [https://vueuse.org](https://vueuse.org) on October 1, 2025.

## File Organization

Each composable has its own markdown file named after the function (e.g., `useMouse.md`, `useStorage.md`). These files contain:

- Function overview and description
- Basic usage examples
- Configuration options
- Component and directive usage (when available)
- Type declarations
- Links to source code

## Additional Resources

- [VueUse Official Documentation](https://vueuse.org)
- [VueUse GitHub Repository](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse)
- [Vue School Video Lessons](https://vueschool.io/lessons?friend=vueuse)

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

// Or as a `ref`:

const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

TypeScript

ts

```
import {

import {
,

const

<HTMLElement>('el')
const

const {

// In a watcher

(

()
})

// Or inside any function
function

  // ...some logic

(() => {

()
  })
}
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

[`v10.6.1`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.6.1) on 11/13/2023

[`e9742`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/e97427f20dc84cd040d2712738bc74ab42c90c11) \- fix: can not read properties of null (reading document) ( [#3544](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3544))

[`v10.6.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.6.0) on 11/9/2023

[`86bd8`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/86bd8e8f355b34a56bd69dc78b9e108f848b6c6a) \- fix: trigger once `onMounted` to get correct inital arrivedStates values ( [#3384](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3384))

[`v10.4.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.4.0) on 8/25/2023

[`c1b29`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/c1b296ccfb07039b2087dec0987c7962dc74a3a8) \- fix: evade edge case when window or document is Proxy ( [#3280](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3280))

[`v10.3.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.3.0) on 7/30/2023

[`dde41`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/dde4166658fe91f277e4d03a3610dc7d6cb83c2e) \- fix: support configurable window ( [#3229](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3229))

[`v10.2.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.2.0) on 6/16/2023

[`8855f`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/8855f246c91f8b56d561eb86b86c99669db99de8) \- fix: support window in setArrivedState ( [#3086](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3086))

[`v10.1.1`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.1.1) on 5/1/2023

between two load more (to avoid too many invokes). * * @default 100 */ ?: number /** * A function that determines whether more content can be loaded for a specific element. * Should return `true` if loading more content is allowed for the given element, * and `false` otherwise. */ ?: ( : ) => boolean } /** * Reactive infinite scroll. * * @see https://vueuse.org/useInfiniteScroll */ export declare export interface UseIdleOptions
  extends ConfigurableWindow,
    ConfigurableEventFilter {
  /**
   * Event names that listen to for detected user activity
   *
   * @default ['mousemove', 'mousedown', 'resize', 'keydown', 'touchstart', 'wheel']
   */

?:
[]
  /**
   * Listen for document visibility change
   *
   * @default true
   */

?: boolean
  /**
   * Initial state of the ref idle
   *
   * @default false
   */

?: boolean
}
export interface UseIdleReturn {

:
<boolean>

:
<number>

: () => void
}
/**
 * Tracks whether the user is being inactive.
 *
 * @see https://vueuse.org/useIdle
 * @param timeout default to 1 minute
 * @param options IdleOptions
 */
export declare function
(

?: number,

?: UseIdleOptions,
): UseIdleReturn
```

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

TypeScript

ts

```

```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

js

import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

TypeScript

ts

```
import {

import {

const

})

// Or inside any function
function

  // ...some logic

(() => {

()
  })
}
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

[`v14.0.0-alpha.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v14.0.0-alpha.0) on 9/1/2025

[`8c521`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/8c521d4e4cebc78f59db70cd137098b7095ed605) \- feat(components)!: refactor components and make them consistent ( [#4912](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4912))

[`v13.4.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v13.4.0) on 6/19/2025

[`135d5`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/135d50715ebf3691bccd14ae6b1e98360473e1c6) \- fix: use mutationObserver to update arrivedState when the DOM is changed ( [#4433](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4433))

[`v12.8.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v12.8.0) on 3/5/2025

[`7432f`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/7432fd1d4f47613a26e9286d2723b87eebfb30f3) \- feat(types): deprecate `MaybeRef` and `MaybeRefOrGetter` in favor of Vue's native ( [#4636](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4636))

[`4b7ab`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/4b7ab552157b512fb93c0773e79c21634e565575) \- fix: handle negative scroll values ( [#4613](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4613))

[`v12.3.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v12.3.0) on 1/2/2025

[`59f75`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/59f75c706aa42be1dd79b86c59d98794069dd0df) \- feat(toValue): deprecate `toValue` from `@vueuse/shared` in favor of Vue's native

[`a033e`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/a033efc3343943ce16d96d7e0e3e81f9ec4a27eb) \- feat(useWindowScroll): use `useScroll` under the hood ( [#4424](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4424))

[`v12.1.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v12.1.0) on 12/22/2024

[`90ff4`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/90ff45e9b87da2d9742b96abe51c92142e6bd7bb) \- fix: to properly report arriveState for elastic scroll ( [#4133](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4133))

[`v12.0.0-beta.1`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v12.0.0-beta.1) on 11/21/2024

[`0a9ed`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/0a9ed589ab0e3a4aa8c7b7a4292757947378c14c) \- feat!: drop Vue 2 support, optimize bundles and clean up ( [#4349](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/4349))

[`v10.10.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.10.0) on 5/27/2024

[`317ca`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/317cab66f56b139e26c2b9f2f9a69b186763fa01) \- fix: sync scroll val to internal state, fix [#3809](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3809) ( [#3817](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3817))

[`v10.8.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.8.0) on 2/20/2024

[`fab86`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/fab863aefe5874b5ac7400a887ea68813830a8dc) \- fix: add `onError` hook and avoid throws by default, fix [#3580](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3580) ( [#3605](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3605))

[`v10.6.1`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.6.1) on 11/13/2023

[`e9742`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/e97427f20dc84cd040d2712738bc74ab42c90c11) \- fix: can not read properties of null (reading document) ( [#3544](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3544))

[`v10.6.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.6.0) on 11/9/2023

[`86bd8`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/86bd8e8f355b34a56bd69dc78b9e108f848b6c6a) \- fix: trigger once `onMounted` to get correct inital arrivedStates values ( [#3384](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3384))

[`v10.4.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.4.0) on 8/25/2023

[`c1b29`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/c1b296ccfb07039b2087dec0987c7962dc74a3a8) \- fix: evade edge case when window or document is Proxy ( [#3280](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3280))

[`v10.3.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.3.0) on 7/30/2023

[`dde41`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/dde4166658fe91f277e4d03a3610dc7d6cb83c2e) \- fix: support configurable window ( [#3229](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3229))

[`v10.2.0`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.2.0) on 6/16/2023

[`8855f`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/8855f246c91f8b56d561eb86b86c99669db99de8) \- fix: support window in setArrivedState ( [#3086](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3086))

[`v10.1.1`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/releases/tag/v10.1.1) on 5/1/2023

[`a88fe`](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/commit/a88fea20bae56649186359ed1e648e76648ea024) \- fix(useInfiniteScroll): re-measure arrived states when async infinite scroll resolves ( [#3030](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/issues/3030))

`flex-direction: column-reverse;` | | `left` | `display: flex;`
`flex-direction: row-reverse;` | | `right` | `display: flex;` | WARNING Make sure to indicate when there is no more content to load with `canLoadMore`, otherwise `onLoadMore` will trigger as long as there is space for more content. ## Directive Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useInfiniteScroll/\#directive-usage) > This function also provides a directive version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components). vue ``` ``` ## Type Declarations [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useInfiniteScroll/\#type-declarations) Show Type Declarations ts ``` type = | HTMLElement | SVGElement | Window | Document | null | undefined export interface < extends = , > extends UseScrollOptions { /** * The minimum distance between the bottom of the element and the bottom of the viewport * * @default 0 */ ?: number /** * The direction in which to listen the scroll. * * @default 'bottom' */ ?: "top" | "bottom" | "left" | "right" /** * The interval time between two load more (to avoid too many invokes). * * @default 100 */ ?: number /** * A function that determines whether more content can be loaded for a specific element. * Should return `true` if loading more content is allowed for the given element, * and `false` otherwise. */ ?: ( : ) => boolean } /** * Reactive infinite scroll. * * @see https://vueuse.org/useInfiniteScroll */ export declare function < extends >( : < >, : ( : < >, ) => , ?: < >, ): { : (): void } ``` ## Source [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useInfiniteScroll/\#source) ### Setting scroll position [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#setting-scroll-position)

Set the `x` and `y` values to make the element scroll to that position.

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

TypeScript

ts

```
import {

import {

const

const {

```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

TypeScript

ts

```
import {
} from '@vueuse/core'
import {
,
,
,
} from 'vue'

const
=
<HTMLElement>('el')
const
=
(false)

const {
} =
(
)

// In a watcher

(
, () => {

()
})

// Or inside any function
function
() {
  // ...some logic

(() => {

()
  })
}
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

### Smooth scrolling [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#smooth-scrolling)

Set `behavior: smooth` to enable smooth scrolling. The `behavior` option defaults to `auto`, which means no smooth scrolling. See the `behavior` option on [`window.scrollTo()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo) for more information.

(

})
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { useTemplateRef } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior: 'smooth' })
// Or as a `ref`:
const smooth = ref(false)
const behavior = computed(() => (smooth.value ? 'smooth' : 'auto'))
const { x, y } = useScroll(el, { behavior })
```

### Recalculate scroll state [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useScroll/\#recalculate-scroll-state)

You can call the `measure()` method to manually update the scroll position and `arrivedState` at any time.

This is useful, for example, after dynamic content changes or when you want to recalculate the scroll state outside of scroll events.

```

(

()
})

// Or inside any function
function

  // ...some logic

(() => {

()
  })
}
```

js

```
import { useScroll } from '@vueuse/core'
import { nextTick, useTemplateRef, watch } from 'vue'
const el = useTemplateRef('el')
const reactiveValue = shallowRef(false)
const { measure } = useScroll(el)
// In a watcher
watch(reactiveValue, () => {
  measure()
})
// Or inside any function
function updateScrollState() {
  // ...some logic
  nextTick(() => {
    measure()
  })
}
```

NOTE

it's recommended to call `measure()` inside `nextTick()`, to ensure the DOM is updated first. The scroll state is initialized automatically `onMount`. You only need to call `measure()` manually if you want to recalculate the state after some dynamic changes.

# useDraggable [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDraggable/\#usedraggable)

Category

[Elements](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Elements)

Export Size

1.37 kB

Last Changed

7 months ago

Make elements draggable.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDraggable/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useDraggable/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Disabled drag and drop

Check the floating boxes

ðŸ‘‹ Drag me!

I am at 457, 80

Renderless component

Position persisted in sessionStorage

492, 150

ðŸ‘‹ Drag here!

Handle that triggers the drag event

I am at 533, 240

Not Use Captured Element

Dragging here will not work

582, 330

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDraggable/\#usage)

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
<HTMLElement>('el')

// `style` will be a helper computed for `left: ?px; top: ?px;`
const {
,
,

(
, {

: {
: 40,
: 40 },
})
</script>

<template>
  <

="

="
"
="position: fixed">
    Drag me! I am at {{
 }}, {{
 }}
  </
>
</template>
```

Set `preventDefault: true` to override the default drag-and-drop behavior of certain elements in the browser.

ts

```
const {
,
,
 } =
(el, {

: true,
  // with `preventDefault: true`
  // you can disable the native behavior (e.g., for img)
  // and control the drag-and-drop, preventing the browser interference.
})
```

## Component Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useDraggable/\#component-usage)

> This function also provides a renderless component version via the `@vueuse/components` package. [Learn more about the usage](https://vueuse.org/guide/components).

vue

```
<template>
  <UseDraggable v-slot="{
,
 }"
="{
: 10,
: 10 }">
    Drag me! I am at {{
 }}, {{
 }}
  </UseDraggable>
</template>
```

For component usage, additional props `storageKey` and `storageType` can be passed to the component and enable the persistence of the element position.

vue

```
<template>
  <UseDraggable
="vueuse-draggable"
="session">
    Refresh the page and I am still in the same position!
  </UseDraggable>
</template>
```

# useMediaQuery [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#usemediaquery)

Reactive [Media Query](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Media_Queries/Testing_media_queries). Once you've created a MediaQueryList object, you can check the result of the query or receive notifications when the result changes.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useMediaQuery/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

```
isLargeScreen: true
prefersDark: false

```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)')
const
 =
('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)')
```

#### Server Side Rendering and Nuxt [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#server-side-rendering-and-nuxt)

If you are using [`useMediaQuery`](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/) with SSR enabled, then you need to specify which screen size you would like to render on the server and before hydration to avoid an hydration mismatch

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)', {

: 768 // Will enable SSR mode and render like if the screen was 768px wide
})

.
(
.
) // always false because ssrWidth of 768px is smaller than 1024px

(() => {

.
(
.
) // false if screen is smaller than 1024px, true if larger than 1024px
})
```

Alternatively you can set this up globally for your app using [`provideSSRWidth`](https://vueuse.org/core/useSSRWidth/)

## Type Declarations [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#type-declarations)

ts

```
/**
 * Reactive Media Query.
 *
 * @see https://vueuse.org/useMediaQuery
 * @param query
 * @param options
 */
export declare function
(

:
<string>,

?:
 & {

?: number
  },
):
<boolean>
```

Reactive [Media Query](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Media_Queries/Testing_media_queries). Once you've created a MediaQueryList object, you can check the result of the query or receive notifications when the result changes.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useMediaQuery/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

```
isLargeScreen: true
prefersDark: false

```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)')
const
 =
('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)')
```

#### Server Side Rendering and Nuxt [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/\#server-side-rendering-and-nuxt)

If you are using [`useMediaQuery`](https://vueuse.org/core/useMediaQuery/) with SSR enabled, then you need to specify which screen size you would like to render on the server and before hydration to avoid an hydration mismatch

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
('(min-width: 1024px)', {

: 768 // Will enable SSR mode and render like if the screen was 768px wide
})

.
(
.
) // always false because ssrWidth of 768px is smaller than 1024px

(() => {

.
(
.
) // false if screen is smaller than 1024px, true if larger than 1024px
})
```

Alternatively you can set this up globally for your app using [`provideSSRWidth`](https://vueuse.org/core/useSSRWidth/)

Reactive document title.

WARNING

This composable isn't compatible with SSR.

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTitle/\#demo)

Title

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTitle/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
()

.
(
.
) // print current title

.
 = 'Hello' // change current title
```

Set initial title immediately:

ts

```
const
 =
('New Title')
```

Pass a `ref` and the title will be updated when the source ref changes:

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
(0)

const
 =
(() => {
  return !
.
 ? 'No message' : `${
.
} new messages`
})

(
) // document title will match with the ref "title"
```

Pass an optional template tag [Vue Meta Title Template](https://vue-meta.nuxtjs.org/guide/metainfo.html) to update the title to be injected into this template:

ts

```
const
 =
('New Title', {

: '%s | My Awesome Website'
})
```

WARNING

`observe` is incompatible with `titleTemplate`.

## Type Declarations [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTitle/\#type-declarations)

?:
<string> | ((
: string) => string)
    }
)

 &

 */
export declare function
(

:
<string | null | undefined>,

?:
,
):
<string | null | undefined>
export declare function

?:
<string | null | undefined>,

?:
,
):
<string | null | undefined>
export type

<typeof
>

# useEventListener [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#useeventlistener)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

588 B

Last Changed

2 months ago

Use EventListener with ease. Register using [addEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener) on mounted, and [removeEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/removeEventListener) automatically on unmounted.

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
, 'visibilitychange', (
) => {

.
(
)
})
```

You can also pass a ref as the event target, [`useEventListener`](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/) will unregister the previous event and register the new one when you change the target.

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
('element')

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})
</script>

<template>
  <
 v-if="cond"
="
">
    Div1
  </
>
  <
 v-else
="
">
    Div2
  </
>
</template>
```

You can also call the returned to unregister the listener.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})

() // This will unregister the listener.
```

Note if your components also run in SSR (Server Side Rendering), you might get errors (like `document is not defined`) because DOM APIs like `document` and `window` are not available in Node.js. To avoid that you can put the logic inside `onMounted` hook.

ts

```
// onMounted will only be called in the client side
// so it guarantees the DOM APIs are available.

(() => {

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
  })
})
```

# useEventListener [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#useeventlistener)

Category

[Browser](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Browser)

Export Size

588 B

Last Changed

2 months ago

Use EventListener with ease. Register using [addEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener) on mounted, and [removeEventListener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/removeEventListener) automatically on unmounted.

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/\#usage)

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

(
, 'visibilitychange', (
) => {

.
(
)
})
```

You can also pass a ref as the event target, [`useEventListener`](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/) will unregister the previous event and register the new one when you change the target.

vue

```
<script setup lang="ts">
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
('element')

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})
</script>

<template>
  <
 v-if="cond"
="
">
    Div1
  </
>
  <
 v-else
="
">
    Div2
  </
>
</template>
```

You can also call the returned to unregister the listener.

ts

```
import {
 } from '@vueuse/core'

const
 =
(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
})

() // This will unregister the listener.
```

Note if your components also run in SSR (Server Side Rendering), you might get errors (like `document is not defined`) because DOM APIs like `document` and `window` are not available in Node.js. To avoid that you can put the logic inside `onMounted` hook.

ts

```
// onMounted will only be called in the client side
// so it guarantees the DOM APIs are available.

(() => {

(
, 'keydown', (
) => {

.
(
.
)
  })
})
```

content.text:
{
  "markdown": "[Skip to content](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/#VPContent)

On this page

# useTransition [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/\#usetransition)

Category

[Animation](https://vueuse.org/functions#category=Animation)

Export Size

912 B

Last Changed

2 weeks ago

Transition between values

## Demo [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/\#demo)

[source](https://github.com/vueuse/vueuse/blob/main/packages/core/useTransition/demo.vue) [playground (beta)](https://playground.vueuse.org/?vueuse=14.0.0-beta.1#)

Transition

Cubic bezier curve: **0.00**

Custom function: **0.00**

Vector: **\[0.00, 0.00\]**

Non-numeric value: **Hello**

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/\#usage)

Define a source value to follow, and when changed the output will transition to the new value. If the source changes while a transition is in progress, a new transition will begin from where the previous one was interrupted.

ts

```
import {
,
 } from '@vueuse/core'
import {
 } from 'vue'

const
 =
(0)

const
 =
(
, {

: 1000,

:
.
,
})
```

Transition easing can be customized using [cubic bezier curves](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function/cubic-bezier#description).

ts

```

(source, {

: [0.75, 0, 0.25, 1],
})
```

The following transitions are available via the `TransitionPresets` constant.

- [`linear`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#0,0,1,1)
- [`easeInSine`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.12,0,.39,0)
- [`easeOutSine`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.61,1,.88,1)
- [`easeInOutSine`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.37,0,.63,1)
- [`easeInQuad`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.11,0,.5,0)

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/\#usage)

Define a source value to follow, and when changed the output will transition to the new value. If the source changes while a transition is in progress, a new transition will begin from where the previous one was interrupted.

```

Transition easing can be customized using [cubic bezier curves](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function/cubic-bezier#description).

```

: [0.75, 0, 0.25, 1],
})
```

## Usage [â€‹](https://vueuse.org/core/useTransition/\#usage)

Define a source value to follow, and when changed the output will transition to the new value. If the source changes while a transition is in progress, a new transition will begin from where the previous one was interrupted.

Transition easing can be customized using [cubic bezier curves](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function/cubic-bezier#description).

: [0.75, 0, 0.25, 1],
})
```

The following transitions are available via the `TransitionPresets` constant.

- [`linear`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#0,0,1,1)
- [`easeInSine`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.12,0,.39,0)
- [`easeOutSine`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.61,1,.88,1)

- [`easeOutQuart`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.25,1,.5,1)
- [`easeInOutQuart`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.76,0,.24,1)
- [`easeInQuint`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.64,0,.78,0)
- [`easeOutQuint`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.22,1,.36,1)

- [`easeInCirc`](https://cubic-bezier.com/#.55,0,1,.45)

You can also pass a ref as the event target, [`useEventListener`](https://vueuse.org/core/useEventListener/) will unregister the previous event and register the new one when you change the target.

You can also call the returned to unregister the listener.

```

const

Note if your components also run in SSR (Server Side Rendering), you might get errors (like `document is not defined`) because DOM APIs like `document` and `window` are not available in Node.js. To avoid that you can put the logic inside `onMounted` hook.

```
